title: Is Cardi B's WAP offensive to parents? - Quora
tags: Female Rappers and Hip Hop Artists

response.answer_text: “I Didn’t Like it the First Time” “If I Can’t Sell It (I’ll keep sittin’ on it, ’cause I ain’t about to give it away)“ “Tonight’s the Night” “Head” “Norwegian Wood” “Go Where You Wanna Go” “Let’s Go Get Stoned” “Baby Got Back” “Fancy” “What’s Love Got to Do With It” “Let’s Get Drunk and Screw” “Badonk-a-donk” “My Neck, My Back” “A Little Bump n Grind” “(Gonna make you) Sweat” “Private Dancer” Listening to music that offends parents has been a form of benign rebellion since (at least) the 1920s. Double-entendre lyrics, plainly overt words about sex, politics, drugs, gangs, violence and the like, have always given the ‘older’ generation fits. If a parent has a problem with adult language about these topics - and yet chooses not to actively control what their child listens to - I’d suggest asking your child ‘what’s that song about?’ This will create an opportunity to discuss the subject matter of the song. Something to remember: you have an opinion of the song, that’s all. Keep the conversation on that level: ‘I don’t really care for that song, because it’s disrespectful of women, it trivializes sex, murder and violence is not entertaining to me, the coarse language is uncomfortable for me’ - whatever your reasons are - ‘if you choose to listen to this or sing this, please do so privately: use your earbuds, or take it to your room.’ Once a person knows something, they can’t un-know it; they can choose to ignore it, but must accept the responsibility.This way, your child has the option of creating a confrontation of disobeying you by playing/singing it in your presence, or listening to it alone, which not nearly as fun watching others’ reactions when profanity or sexual lyrics are heard. Young people need to test their limits of what’s possible, what they can ‘get away with’, and what the consequences are - that’s how they grow, how they learn responsibility. It’s important that parents are honest and consistent with rules and opinions, but understand that the era of total control over your children is long gone. TV, movies, the internet and their peers bombard them constantly with what’s good, what’s new, what’s stupid, what ‘everybody does’, what ‘everybody needs’. Talking with them regularly about how we parents feel, and what impressions their actions project, and what consequences may await them, help them to make better choices - for themselves, not necessarily for the comfort of the parents.
